DEPTOWNERNAME: Barbara J. and Roger W. Rossier School of Education

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to the software engineering process and software lifecycle. Covers project management, requirements, architecture, design, implementation, testing, and maintenance phase activities in team based projects. Prerequisites: CSCI 201. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 377.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Basic issues in concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization scheduling, memory management, protection and access control, inter-process communication, and structured design. Laboratory experiences with Unix-like operating system. Duplicates credit in CSCI 402.

(Duplicates credit in former CSCI 562)
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and disc rete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Standard techniques in the design and analysis of randomized algorithms and random structures. Topics include tail bounds, Markov Chains, VC-dimension, probabilistic method. Prerequisite: CSCI 570 or CSCI 670. Recommended preparation: Basic background in probability and linear algebra.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. Students must have a specific job/internship offer. Job must be related to students major. Students must have been in F-1 student status for at least one academic year in a degree-seeking program before they can apply for CPT, with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. Course does not apply to degree credit. Open only to graduate students.

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: Identity Development of the Contemporary Female
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Exploration of identity development in terms of social, political, and cultural constructs; examination of collegiate athletics and the contributions of women of color.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Exploration of the ways in which developments and policies, including neoliberalism, the carceral state, and economic precarity, are connected and gendered.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Analysis of transgender behaviors, from androgyny and transvestism to transexuality. Discussion of changing laws, representations, medical standards, and social attitudes towards transgender and intersex people.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: Senior Seminar in Gender and Sexuality Studies
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Application of gender and sexuality research methods to individual student projects with an emphasis on feminist, queer and post-colonial scholarship.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Independent research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: Introduction to Visual Studies:Methods and Debates
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: A critical introduction to the field of visual studies focusing on interdisciplinary approaches to images, objects, and visual technologies as well as key texts and interpretive debates.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Populations, permutations, combinations, random variables, distribution and density functions, conditional probability and expectation,; binomial, poisson, and normal distributions; laws of large numbers, central limit theorem.Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: a: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions. b: Dependence, martingales, ergodic theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Brownian motion, stochastic integrals, the Ito formula, stochastic differential equations, analysis of diffusion processes, Girsanov transformation, Feynmann-Kac formula, applications.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: A: Group Theory: Isomorphism theorems, group actions, Sylow's theorems, simple and solvable groups; Field Theory: Galois correspondence, radical extensions, algebraic and transcendental extensions, finite fields.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: a: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation. Prerequisite: 425ab. b: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp, Hilbert spaces, orthogonalexpansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions. Prerequisite: 525a.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Stochastic processes revisited, Brownian motion, Martingale theory, stochastic differential equations, Feynman-Kac formula, binomial models, basic concepts in arbitrage pricing theory, equivalent Martingale measure. Recommended preparation: Math-225, Math-407. Duplicates credit in the former MATH-50 3
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Inversion formulas, generating functions and recursions, partitions, Stirling numbers, distinct representatives, Ramsey's theorem, graph theory, block designs, difference sets, finite geometrics, Latin squares, Hadamard matrices.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Initial and final topologies, function spaces, algebras in C(Y), homotopy, fundamental group, fiber spaces and bundles, smashes, loop spaces, groups of homotopy classes, cw- complexes. Prerequisite: 440.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic,parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave equations.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Metric spaces, compactness, completion, fixed-point theorems, abstract spaces, linear operators, functionals, duality, conjugates, Lp spaces, Fourier transform. Applications from Engineering, Natural and Social sciences. Recommended preparation: Linear Algebra and Calculus.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Equivalence of matrices; Jordon canonical form; functions of matrices; diagonalization; singular value decomposition; applications to linear differential equations, stability theory, and Markov processes. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and comutational sciences to data from molecular biology. Statistics for genomic sequence data: DNA sequence assembly, significance of alignment scores, hidden Markov models, genetic mapping, models of sequence evolution, and microarray analysis.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Basic functional analysis in Banach and Hilbert spaces. Weaktopologies, linear operators, spectral theory, calculus of vector-valued functions. Banach algebras.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Investigation of energy technologies, including development and implementation issues. Topics include the Industrial Revolution, electromagnetic induction, power transmission, combustion engines, fission and fusion. Not available for major credit.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Dynamics of particles, kinematics of rotations, rigid body motion, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalism, theory of small vibrations.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: a: Electrostatics; thermal, chemical, magnetic effects of steady currents; DC circuits.

COURSE_TITLE: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Relativity, atomic spectra, quantum statistics, nuclear models, nuclear reactions, elementary particles.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_TITLE: Physical Biology: From Molecules to Cells
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Length, time, and energy scales of life; statistical mechanics of biomolecules and cellular processes; physics of cell shape; biological fluid dynamics; electron transfer and metabolism. Recommended preparation: BISC 220. Prerequisites: PHYS 152 or PHYS 162.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Projects will include experiments in mechanics, thermodynamics,electricity and magnetism.Emphasis on laboratory work with discussion of theoretical background.Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 6 hours.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Topics of current research interest in physics and astronomy.Lectures directed to physics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers.Graded CR/NC.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Newtonian formulation of dynamics; Hamilton's principle; Lagrangian formulation; rigid body motion; Hamiltonian formulation; Hamilton-Jacobi theory; vibrations.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: a: Electrostatics, boundary value problems, multiple expansions, microscopic models of matter, magnetostatics. b: Maxwell's equations, potentials and gauge transformations; electromagnetic waves; wave guides; electromagnetic radiation; special relativity.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Vector analysis; infinite, asymptotic Fourier series; complete sets; Dirac delta function; Fourier, Laplace transforms; Legendre functions; spherical harmonics; Sturm-Liouville theory; orthogonal polynomials; gamma-factorial function; complex variables.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Principles of, and relations between, thermodynamics, and statistical mechanics; ensembles, partition function formalism; quantum statistics; fluctuations.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: b: Approximation schemes and application to atomic and molecular physics and scattering theory; identical particles; electromagnetic properties of atoms.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics
LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Magnetism, magnons; superconductivity; transport phenomena;many-body effects; interacting electron gas; Hartee-Fock theory; neutron and x-ray scattering; and other selected topics. Recommended preparation PHYS 540 and PHYS 558b.

COURSE_TITLE: Black Social Movements in the U.S.
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: This course examines black social movements for freedom, justice, equality, and self determination. Beginning with Reconstruction, movements include labor, civil rights, radical feminism, socialism, reparations, Black Nationalism, prisoners' rights, and Hip Hop.
